title-group.article-title: Association of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection and Incident Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Among 143,001 Veterans

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: People with human immunodeficiency virus (PWH) have an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Prior cross-sectional data suggest there is a higher prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in PWH than in those without HIV. Whether PWH have an increased risk of incident AAA compared to those without HIV is unknown.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We analyzed data among participants without prevalent AAA from the Veterans Aging Cohort Study, a prospective, observational, longitudinal cohort of veterans living with HIV and matched 1:2 with veterans living without HIV infection. We calculated AAA rates by HIV status and assessed the association between HIV infection and incident AAA using Cox proportional hazards models. We defined AAA using ICD-9/ICD-10/CPT codes and adjusted all models for demographics, CVD risk factors, and substance use. Secondary analyses examined the association between time varying CD4+ T cell count or HIV viral load and incident AAA.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Among 143,001 participants (43,766 with HIV), over a median follow-up of 8.7 years, there were 2,431 incident AAA events (26.4% among PWH). Rates of incident AAA per 1000 person-years were similar among PWH (2.0; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.9–2.2) and people without HIV (2.2; 95% CI, 2.1–2.3). There was no evidence that HIV infection increased the risk of incident AAA compared to no HIV infection (adjusted hazard ratio [HRadj], 1.02; 95% CI, 0.92–1.13). In adjusted analyses with time-varying CD4+ T cell counts or HIV viral load, PWH with CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/mm3 (HRadj, 1.29; 95% CI, 1.02–1.65) or HIV viral load ≥ 500 copies/mL (HRadj, 1.29; 95% CI, 1.09–1.52) had an increased risk of AAA compared to those without HIV.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: HIV infection is associated with an increased risk of AAA among those with low CD4+ T cell counts or elevated HIV viral load over time.

abstract.title: Brief Summary:
abstract.p: In the Veterans Aging Cohort Study, people with HIV and controlled virus were not at higher risk of developing AAA than people without HIV.
